content.raw:
This seems to fix the issue we had in the lab.

Shouldn't we also add this rounding to all the other ramp functions we have just to be save?
content.html:
This seems to fix the issue we had in the lab.

Shouldn't we also add this rounding to all the other ramp functions we have just to be save?

content.raw:
Yes you're right. Also, I think that I shouldn't have added in `truncation` where I did because that will change the shape of the ramp if it isn't 1...I think?

Presumably that is fine because you wouldn't expect to run up to a limit if you are truncating \(I mean it's theoretically possible you could parameterise a ramp so that is extended over a limit but then you truncated, but that's pretty odd and I think in that case those users can deal with floating point rounding error themselves!\)
content.html:
Yes you're right. Also, I think that I shouldn't have added in truncation where I did because that will change the shape of the ramp if it isn't 1...I think?

Presumably that is fine because you wouldn't expect to run up to a limit if you are truncating (I mean it's theoretically possible you could parameterise a ramp so that is extended over a limit but then you truncated, but that's pretty odd and I think in that case those users can deal with floating point rounding error themselves!)

content.raw:
I never used truncation until now but yes you should remove it where you added it. Otherwise it would turn into a squished ramp in stead of cutting of parts.

Well if you have a truncation greater 1 you will overshoot anyway. And if anyone ever runs into a rounding error because of their truncation being totally off we should handle it then. 

By the way I figured our why the time was so overly precise: It contained a global that was generated by a numpy linspace.
content.html:
I never used truncation until now but yes you should remove it where you added it. Otherwise it would turn into a squished ramp in stead of cutting of parts.

Well if you have a truncation greater 1 you will overshoot anyway. And if anyone ever runs into a rounding error because of their truncation being totally off we should handle it then.

By the way I figured our why the time was so overly precise: It contained a global that was generated by a numpy linspace.

content.raw: The truncation mistake is now fixed and the fix has been applied to all other ramping functions of `AnalogQuantity`
content.html: The truncation mistake is now fixed and the fix has been applied to all other ramping functions of AnalogQuantity
